queries.company_overview:
What it does: Microsoft develops and licenses software, cloud services, and devices globally. It operates at scale across cloud infrastructure and AI (Azure), productivity and collaboration (Microsoft 365/Copilot, Teams, LinkedIn), Windows, and gaming (Xbox/Activision).

Main business units / segments:
- Productivity and Business Processes (Microsoft 365/Office, LinkedIn, Dynamics)
- Intelligent Cloud (Azure, server products, GitHub, Nuance)
- More Personal Computing (Windows, Devices/Surface, Gaming/Xbox, Search and news advertising)

High-level financials: FY2024 revenue $245.1B; FY2024 net income $88.1B (USD). Market capitalization: $3,960B as of 2025-10-28.

Competitive positioning: Microsoft competes with AWS and Google Cloud in cloud infrastructure; Azure is the second-largest global provider behind AWS. In productivity, Microsoft 365 competes with Google Workspace and benefits from a large enterprise installed base and integration across Windows, Office, and Teams. In devices and gaming, it competes with Apple and Sony/Nintendo, leveraging platform scale and cross-ecosystem distribution.

Recent major news:
- 2025-10-23 Microsoft announced Copilot Fall Release with 'Mico' avatar and new features across Windows and Edge.
- 2025-10-14 Microsoft issued October Patch Tuesday addressing 172 flaws, including six zero-days.
- 2025-09-18 Microsoft committed an additional $4B for 'Fairwater' AI datacenter in Wisconsin, total investment >$7B.
- 2025-09-12 European Commission accepted legally binding commitments on unbundling Teams and improving interoperability/data portability.
- 2025-07-30 Reported FY25 Q4 results: revenue $76.4B, net income $27.2B; Microsoft Cloud revenue $46.7B.

What is the release schedule for Azure M.query: What is the release schedule for Azure Maia and Cobalt chip generations through 2026?
What is the release schedule for Azure M.answer: Microsoft began rolling out its first-gen chips in 2024: Azure Maia 100 (AI accelerator) and Azure Cobalt 100 (Arm CPU), with Cobalt 100-based VMs reaching general availability in December 2024 and expanding in 2025. According to reporting summarized by DataCenterDynamics, the next-gen Maia 200 (Braga) has slipped to mass production in 2026 (originally 2025), with Braga‑R and Maia 300 following later. Microsoft says it is designing second‑generation Cobalt CPUs, but has not publicly committed to a 2025–2026 release date.

search_results.title: Microsoft delays production of Maia 200 AI chip to 2026 - report
search_results.snippet: Citing The Information, Microsoft’s next Maia chip (codename Braga, to be branded Maia 200) has had mass production pushed to 2026; the internal roadmap listed Braga (2025), Braga‑R (2026), and Clea (Maia 300, 2027), while Maia 100 was unveiled in Nov 2023.

search_results.title: Azure Cobalt 100-based Virtual Machines are now generally available
search_results.snippet: Microsoft announces GA of Azure Cobalt 100-based VMs, its first fully in‑house 64‑bit Arm CPU, with broad regional availability and expansion planned in 2024 and beyond—confirming the initial Cobalt 100 rollout timeline.

search_results.title: With a systems approach to chips, Microsoft aims to tailor everything ‘from silicon to service’ to meet AI demand
search_results.snippet: At Ignite, Microsoft unveiled the Azure Maia AI Accelerator and Azure Cobalt CPU, saying the chips would start rolling out to datacenters early the following year, and noted it is already designing second‑generation versions of both the Maia and Cobalt series.

What benchmarks show Microsoft models ou.query: What benchmarks show Microsoft models outperforming competitors in 2025, including MMLU or GPT-4-class evaluations?
What benchmarks show Microsoft models ou.answer: In 2025, Microsoft’s 14B-parameter Phi-4 and Phi-4-reasoning models are reported to outperform or match larger competitors on multiple benchmarks. Microsoft shows Phi-4 on the Pareto frontier for MMLU-Pro and ahead on competition math, while Phi-4-reasoning(+ ) rival or exceed GPT-4-class models (OpenAI o1-mini/o3-mini) and DeepSeek-R1-Distill-Llama-70B on AIME 2025, OmniMath, GPQA, and coding tests. Independent reporting also notes Phi-4 surpassing GPT-4o, Llama 3.3-70B, and Qwen 2.5 on GPQA and MATH.

search_results.title: Phi-Reasoning: Once again redefining what is possible with small and efficient AI
search_results.snippet: Microsoft reports that its 14B Phi‑4‑reasoning and Phi‑4‑reasoning‑plus models outperform OpenAI’s o1‑mini and DeepSeek‑R1‑Distill‑Llama‑70B on most benchmarks and approach DeepSeek‑R1 on AIME 2025; they also beat Claude 3.7 Sonnet and Gemini 2 Flash Thinking except on GPQA and Calendar Planning. The evaluations span AIME 2025, HMMT, OmniMath, GPQA, and LiveCodeBench—evidence of GPT‑4‑class competitiveness in 2025.

search_results.title: Microsoft's Phi-4 Blends Synthetic and Organic Data to Surpass Larger Models in Math and Reasoning Benchmarks
search_results.snippet: DeepLearning.ai writes that Phi‑4 (14B) outperforms Llama 3.3‑70B, Qwen 2.5 (72B), and even GPT‑4o on GPQA and MATH; across 13 benchmarks, it beats Llama 3.3‑70B on six and Qwen 2.5 on five, though Llama 3.3 leads on DROP and SimpleQA. This independent coverage corroborates Microsoft’s claims of superior 2025 benchmark performance.

search_results.title: Phi-4
search_results.snippet: Microsoft’s January 2025 Phi‑4 brief shows the 14B model at the Pareto frontier on MMLU‑Pro (performance vs parameters) and outperforming much larger models on competition‑math benchmarks, with examples including comparisons to Gemini Pro 1.5. It emphasizes post‑training innovations and data quality as drivers of these results.

How much AI training compute has Microso.query: How much AI training compute has Microsoft allocated for OpenAI use in 2025-2026?
How much AI training compute has Microso.answer: Microsoft has not disclosed a specific amount of AI training compute allocated to OpenAI for 2025–2026. In January 2025, it said OpenAI made a “new, large Azure commitment” and shifted to a right‑of‑first‑refusal model on new capacity, but provided no numbers. Separately, Microsoft plans about $80 billion of AI data center investment in FY2025, underscoring overall scale but not a precise 2025–2026 allocation for OpenAI.

search_results.title: Microsoft and OpenAI evolve partnership to drive the next phase of AI
search_results.snippet: Microsoft said OpenAI made a new, large Azure commitment that will support all OpenAI products and training, and changed exclusivity on new capacity to a right‑of‑first‑refusal model while approving OpenAI to build additional capacity for research and training; no numeric compute allocation is provided.

search_results.title: Microsoft is no longer OpenAI’s exclusive cloud provider
search_results.snippet: TechCrunch reports the new deal ends Azure exclusivity for new capacity but gives Microsoft right of first refusal on OpenAI’s workloads and notes a new, large Azure commitment to support products and training; the article does not quantify how much training compute is allocated.

search_results.title: Microsoft to spend $80bn on AI data centers in 2025
search_results.snippet: Microsoft’s Brad Smith said the company plans about $80 billion of FY2025 investment in AI-enabled data centers to train AI models and deploy applications, indicating the scale of available capacity that can support partners like OpenAI, though it does not specify any dedicated 2025–2026 allocation for OpenAI.

What is Microsoft's 2026 roadmap for Phi.query: What is Microsoft's 2026 roadmap for Phi-3 and future small language models?
What is Microsoft's 2026 roadmap for Phi.answer: Microsoft’s 2026 roadmap builds on Phi‑3 by expanding the Phi family with Phi‑4 variants (mini, multimodal, and reasoning) and pushing these small language models to run on-device, especially on Copilot+ PCs via NPU‑optimized Phi Silica and task‑specific micro‑SLMs like Mu. The models remain openly available in Azure AI Foundry, Hugging Face, and NVIDIA’s API catalog, with emphasis on long context, multimodality, agentic reasoning, and low‑latency edge deployment across Windows and partner devices.

search_results.title: One year of Phi: Small language models making big leaps in AI
search_results.snippet: Microsoft outlines the step beyond Phi‑3 with Phi‑4‑reasoning, ‑reasoning‑plus and ‑mini‑reasoning—models trained for inference‑time scaling and complex tasks that can run locally on Windows 11 devices. It highlights NPU‑optimized Phi Silica variants for Copilot+ PCs and ONNX‑optimized releases for Snapdragon NPUs, signaling a roadmap of small, agentic reasoning models integrated across Windows and edge.

search_results.title: Empowering innovation: The next generation of the Phi family
search_results.snippet: Microsoft announces Phi‑4‑multimodal (5.6B) and Phi‑4‑mini (3.8B), available in Azure AI Foundry, Hugging Face, and NVIDIA’s API Catalog, designed for on‑device use with ONNX Runtime. These SLMs add long‑context, function‑calling and multimodal capabilities while staying small enough for low‑latency edge deployment and economical fine‑tuning—framing the next phase of the Phi roadmap after Phi‑3.

search_results.title: Introducing Mu language model and how it enabled the agent in Windows Settings
search_results.snippet: Windows introduces Mu, a 330M on‑device small language model powering the Settings agent on Copilot+ PCs, fully offloaded to the NPU and exceeding 100 tokens/second. Built from Phi Silica learnings, Mu reflects Microsoft’s plan to deploy task‑specific micro‑SLMs across Windows experiences, with the team inviting feedback as it iterates on what’s ahead.

What investments is Microsoft making in.query: What investments is Microsoft making in retrieval augmented generation tooling within GitHub and Azure AI Studio?
What investments is Microsoft making in.answer: Microsoft is bringing RAG natively into GitHub through GitHub Models RAG, powered by Azure AI Search, with a built‑in Playground, ready‑to‑run code using a GitHub PAT, and an auto‑provisioned free Azure AI Search service that supports hybrid, vector, and semantic ranking. In Azure AI Studio (Azure AI Foundry), Microsoft has made RAG a first‑class concept with an Index asset that standardizes where and how data is searched (vector/keyword/hybrid), and uses Azure AI Search as the recommended store. They are also upgrading the retrieval stack itself—introducing Generative Query Rewriting and a new Semantic Ranker in Azure AI Search—to improve RAG relevance and latency, with these capabilities flowing into GitHub Models and Azure AI experiences.

search_results.title: GitHub Models: Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG)
search_results.snippet: Microsoft announced RAG for GitHub Models, powered by Azure AI Search, to let developers ground models on their own data directly in GitHub. It includes a RAG Playground for file uploads, ready‑to‑use code with only a GitHub PAT, and an auto‑provisioned free Azure AI Search service—all with full query API access (hybrid, vector, semantic ranker). The post notes new search features like query rewriting will be added and made available in GitHub Models RAG.

search_results.title: Retrieval augmented generation in Azure AI Foundry portal
search_results.snippet: Azure AI Foundry (Azure AI Studio) treats RAG as a first‑class pattern and provides an Index asset that codifies where the index lives, how it’s accessed, supported search modes (keyword, semantic, vector, hybrid), and the embedding model used. It recommends Azure AI Search as the primary index store for RAG, making retrieval and grounding an integrated part of Studio projects.

search_results.title: Raising the bar for RAG excellence: query rewriting and new semantic ranker
search_results.snippet: Microsoft introduced two retrieval upgrades for Azure AI Search that directly improve RAG quality: Generative Query Rewriting (a fine‑tuned SLM generates up to 10 query variants, boosting recall) and a new, faster Semantic Ranker model. Together they deliver significant relevance gains (e.g., up to +22 NDCG@3 with QR) with automatic rollout, reinforcing RAG retrieval across GitHub Models and Azure AI experiences.

What are Microsoft's 2025-2026 patent fi.query: What are Microsoft's 2025-2026 patent filings related to AI model training and inference optimizations?
What are Microsoft's 2025-2026 patent fi.answer: In 2025, Microsoft filed/published patents that optimize both training and inference for LLMs. On the inference side, Microsoft proposes routing prompts based on a learned query complexity score to conserve compute by sending easy queries to smaller models and hard queries to larger ones. On the training side, filings describe learning generalized instruction prompts from past model self-reflections to reduce inference-time iterations, and selecting minimal, high-impact one/few-shot code examples via symbolic property mining to improve code generation efficiency. As of late 2025, comparable 2026 publications in this specific area are not broadly visible yet.

search_results.title: Patents Assigned to Microsoft Technolog Licensing, LLC
search_results.snippet: Lists Microsoft’s 2025 application US 2025/0272313 (Systems and methods for resource conservation based on query complexity), which classifies input query difficulty with a response classifier and routes prompts to either a smaller or larger LLM to lower COGS, latency, and compute while maintaining quality; published Aug 28, 2025.

search_results.title: META-REFLECTION TECHNIQUES FOR LEARNING INSTRUCTIONS FOR LANGUAGE AGENTS USING PAST SELF-REFLECTIONS
search_results.snippet: Microsoft’s 2025 filing teaches using past model self-reflections during training to learn generalized instruction prompts that are injected at inference, reducing back-and-forth and compute while improving language-agent performance; assigned to Microsoft Technology Licensing, and published Oct 23, 2025.

search_results.title: TARGET PROPERTY SELECTION TECHNIQUES FOR LEARNING WHAT TO TEACH LANGUAGE MODELS FOR CODE GENERATION
search_results.snippet: Describes mining symbolic properties from one-shot examples and training a property recognition model to pick the most relevant minimal examples for few-shot prompting, improving efficiency and accuracy in LLM code generation; assigned to Microsoft Technology Licensing, and published Oct 23, 2025.

What FY2026 revenue guidance did Microso.query: What FY2026 revenue guidance did Microsoft provide by segment in July 2025 earnings materials?
What FY2026 revenue guidance did Microso.answer: In its July 2025 earnings materials (FY25 Q4), Microsoft guided Q1 FY2026 segment revenue as follows: Productivity and Business Processes at $32.2–$32.5 billion, Intelligent Cloud at $30.1–$30.4 billion, and More Personal Computing at $12.4–$12.9 billion. Management also flagged Azure and other cloud services growth of about 37% in constant currency.

search_results.title: Microsoft Says It Expects FY26 Revenue Growth In Double-Digits
search_results.snippet: Reuters reports Microsoft’s Q1 FY26 outlook: Intelligent Cloud revenue $30.1–$30.4B; Productivity and Business Processes $32.2–$32.5B; More Personal Computing $12.4–$12.9B; Azure and other cloud services growth about 37% in constant currency; capex over $30B.

search_results.title: Microsoft sees Q1 Intelligent Cloud revenue $30.1B-$30.4B
search_results.snippet: Business Insider relays Microsoft’s Q1 FY26 segment guidance: Productivity and Business Processes $32.2–$32.5B; Intelligent Cloud $30.1–$30.4B; More Personal Computing $12.4–$12.9B; Azure growth 37% in constant currency; currency to add ~2 pts to total revenue growth.

search_results.title: Microsoft Q4 Beats, Cloud Demand Fuels Confidence
search_results.snippet: GuruFocus summarizes Microsoft’s Q1 FY26 guide: total revenue midpoint ~ $75.25B, with segment ranges—PBP $32.2–$32.5B, Intelligent Cloud $30.1–$30.4B, and More Personal Computing $12.4–$12.9B; Azure growth set to accelerate to 37% as capacity remains tight.

Which datasets and data partnerships pow.query: Which datasets and data partnerships power Microsoft Copilot and Azure OpenAI training pipelines in 2025?
Which datasets and data partnerships pow.answer: In 2025, Microsoft states that Copilot and Azure OpenAI do not use customer/tenant data, prompts, or outputs to train foundation models; any fine‑tuned models stay private to the customer. The base models behind Copilot (served via Azure OpenAI) are trained by OpenAI on a mix of publicly available data and licensed/partner content. OpenAI’s data partnerships include major publishers (e.g., Le Monde and Prisa Media, with the Associated Press and Axel Springer also cited) that contribute content for model training, and stock media libraries like Shutterstock that license large multimodal datasets (images, video, music, metadata) as high‑quality training data.

search_results.title: Data, privacy, and security for Azure Direct Models in Azure AI Foundry
search_results.snippet: Microsoft explains that Azure Direct Models (including Azure OpenAI) process data within Azure and do not use customer prompts, outputs, embeddings, or fine‑tuning data to train generative foundation models; this data isn’t shared with OpenAI and fine‑tuned models remain exclusive to the customer.

search_results.title: Data, Privacy, and Security for Microsoft 365 Copilot
search_results.snippet: Microsoft 365 Copilot grounds LLMs with Microsoft Graph data but: prompts, responses, and Graph‑accessed data aren’t used to train foundation LLMs; processing uses Azure OpenAI and stays within Microsoft’s service boundary, aligning with enterprise privacy and compliance commitments.

search_results.title: Global news partnerships: Le Monde and Prisa Media
search_results.snippet: OpenAI confirms that licensed content from Le Monde and Prisa Media will appear in ChatGPT and “will also contribute to the training of our models”; the post also cites the Associated Press and Axel Springer as partners whose content contributes to model training, evidencing the licensing deals that power Copilot’s underlying OpenAI models.

What is Microsoft's 2025 hiring plan for.query: What is Microsoft's 2025 hiring plan for AI researchers and engineers by region and headcount?
What is Microsoft's 2025 hiring plan for.answer: Microsoft has not published a formal 2025 hiring plan that breaks down AI researcher/engineer headcount by region. Public sources show targeted AI hiring in the UK (via the new Microsoft AI London hub) and in the US (Mountain View and Redmond roles), while overall company headcount remained roughly flat at about 228,000 in FY2025 amid broader layoffs and role mix shifts. In practice, AI hiring appears selective and hub-focused rather than a disclosed region-by-region headcount ramp.

search_results.title: Microsoft cut product R&D jobs, added operations roles over the past year, new filing confirms
search_results.snippet: Microsoft’s FY2025 10-K shows global headcount steady at 228,000; R&D employment fell by ~1,000 while operations rose by ~3,000. Initial May layoffs (~6,000) and early July cuts (~9,000) occurred, yet continued hiring kept overall headcount flat—indicating workforce rebalancing rather than a disclosed regional AI hiring rollout.

search_results.title: Announcing new Microsoft AI Hub in London
search_results.snippet: Microsoft AI is opening a London hub led by Jordan Hoffmann and making a significant, long-term investment in the UK. The post says Microsoft will be posting openings and actively hiring AI scientists and engineers to advance language models, infrastructure, and tooling—evidence of UK-focused AI recruitment.

search_results.title: Member of Technical Staff, AI – Multimodal — Microsoft AI jobs
search_results.snippet: Microsoft AI is recruiting for AI Multimodal roles located in Mountain View, CA and Redmond, WA. Responsibilities include model architecture, experiments, and data pipelines—demonstrating active US hiring for AI researchers and engineers across key hubs.

What in-house foundation models did Micr.query: What in-house foundation models did Microsoft publicly release in 2025, including MAI-1-Preview and MAI-Vision-1 timeline?
What in-house foundation models did Micr.answer: In 2025 Microsoft publicly rolled out multiple in‑house models. On Aug 28 it announced MAI‑1‑preview (its first end‑to‑end trained foundation LLM, put into public testing on LMArena) alongside the MAI‑Voice‑1 speech model and began limited Copilot rollouts. In mid‑October it revealed MAI‑Image‑1, its first in‑house text‑to‑image model, publicly tested on LMArena and slated for Copilot/Bing integration. By the Oct 23 Copilot Fall Release, Microsoft confirmed it had also released MAI‑Vision‑1, placing its debut by late October with product integration underway.

search_results.title: Human-centered AI | Microsoft Copilot Blog
search_results.snippet: Microsoft’s Copilot Fall Release post confirms that in the past few months it released in‑house models MAI‑Voice‑1, MAI‑1‑Preview and MAI‑Vision‑1, with product integration underway—placing MAI‑Vision‑1’s debut by late Oct 2025 and situating it alongside the August and October model launches.

search_results.title: Microsoft unveils home-made ML models amid OpenAI negotiations
search_results.snippet: Coverage of Microsoft AI’s Aug 28, 2025 announcement of its first two in‑house models: MAI‑Voice‑1 (now in Copilot Labs, Daily and Podcasts) and MAI‑1‑preview (public testing on LMArena; first end‑to‑end foundation model trained on ~15,000 H100 GPUs), with rollout to select Copilot text use cases in the following weeks.

search_results.title: Microsoft AI Debuts MAI-Image-1: An In-House Text-to-Image Model that Enters LMArena’s Top-10
search_results.snippet: Details Microsoft’s Oct 2025 reveal of MAI‑Image‑1, its first in‑house text‑to‑image model; publicly tested on LMArena (Top‑10) and planned for Copilot and Bing Image Creator—marking the mid‑October step in the 2025 in‑house model timeline after MAI‑1‑preview/MAI‑Voice‑1.

What binding EU commitments did Microsof.query: What binding EU commitments did Microsoft accept on 2025-09-12 to resolve Teams tying concerns?
What binding EU commitments did Microsof.answer: On 2025-09-12, the European Commission made Microsoft’s commitments legally binding to resolve Teams tying concerns. Microsoft must sell Office/Microsoft 365 suites without Teams at lower prices (with increased price gaps), let EEA customers on long‑term contracts switch to no‑Teams suites with discount parity, ensure effective interoperability (including embedding Office Web Apps, add-ins and APIs) and enable data portability/export from Teams, and display like‑for‑like offers and publish technical information. Most obligations last 7 years (10 years for interoperability and data portability), overseen by a monitoring trustee with fast‑track arbitration and potential fines for non‑compliance.

search_results.title: Commission accepts commitments offered by Microsoft to address competition concerns related to Teams
search_results.snippet: The Commission made Microsoft’s commitments binding: sell Office/Microsoft 365 without Teams at reduced prices; allow EEA customers with long‑term licenses to switch to no‑Teams suites; ensure interoperability (incl. embedding Office Web Apps and integration with Outlook/Word) and allow export of Teams data; and, after market testing, increase price gaps by 50% for some suites, show with/without‑Teams offers side‑by‑side, and publish developer information. Commitments run 7 years (10 for interoperability/data portability), monitored by a trustee with fast‑track arbitration and fines for non‑compliance.

search_results.title: Evolving our productivity offerings to resolve European competition concerns about Teams
search_results.snippet: Microsoft details the binding EU commitments: maintain an open add‑in model and marketplace; allow rivals to embed Office Web Apps via MDCPP; provide APIs giving access to data from Entra ID, Exchange Online, SharePoint and OneDrive equivalent to Teams; offer Teams data migration APIs and a no‑cost export tool; implement mandated minimum price deltas between suites with and without Teams; and allow EEA customers on multi‑year contracts to switch to no‑Teams suites with discount parity.

search_results.title: Microsoft makes commitments on Teams to allay EU antitrust concerns
search_results.snippet: The EU accepted Microsoft’s concessions to resolve the Teams tying case: unbundle Teams from Office/Microsoft 365 at a lower price with discount parity, offer interoperability to rivals, and allow extraction of Teams messaging data. The decision binds Microsoft for seven years (ten years for interoperability and data portability) with fines up to 10% of global revenue for non‑compliance.

search_results.snippet: On the Q4 FY25 call, CFO Amy Hood guided that Microsoft Cloud gross margin percentage should be about 67% in Q1 FY26, down year over year, explicitly attributing the decline to the continued scaling of AI infrastructure; management indicated cloud gross margin would remain pressured as AI capacity is built out.

search_results.snippet: Microsoft disclosed that Microsoft Cloud gross margin percentage was 71% in FY25 Q1 and that the decrease was driven by scaling AI infrastructure—providing the prior-year baseline that frames FY26’s guided ~67% cloud gross margin as a roughly four-point YoY headwind from AI build-out.

search_results.title: Microsoft (MSFT) Q4 2025 Earnings Call Transcript - Longbridge
search_results.snippet: The transcript summary highlights FY26 guidance: management expects double‑digit growth but notes Microsoft Cloud gross margin will decline as AI infrastructure scaling persists; Q1 FY26 capex is guided over $30B and cloud gross margin is guided at ~67%, underscoring ongoing AI‑driven margin pressure.

What major Microsoft cybersecurity incid.query: What major Microsoft cybersecurity incidents were disclosed in 2025 and how were customers impacted?
What major Microsoft cybersecurity incid.answer: In 2025, Microsoft disclosed three notable security issues affecting customers in different ways. First, a mass exploitation campaign hit on‑premises SharePoint servers (CVE‑2025‑49704/49706, later CVE‑2025‑53770/53771), leading to hundreds of confirmed compromises worldwide and impacting U.S. government agencies; customers had to urgently apply patches, rotate ASP.NET machine keys, restart IIS, and investigate for web shells and possible ransomware. Second, a Windows CLFS zero‑day (CVE‑2025‑29824) was exploited post‑compromise by Storm‑2460 to escalate privileges and deploy ransomware against a small number of organizations, prompting immediate patching and ransomware mitigations. Third, the EchoLeak flaw in Microsoft 365 Copilot (CVE‑2025‑32711) could have silently exfiltrated sensitive tenant data via prompt injection, but Microsoft fixed it server‑side in May with no evidence of in‑the‑wild exploitation and no customer action required.

search_results.title: What we know about the Microsoft SharePoint attacks
search_results.snippet: In July 2025, state-linked hackers and ransomware groups exploited on‑premises Microsoft SharePoint flaws (CVE‑2025‑49704/49706), later requiring emergency fixes (CVE‑2025‑53770/53771). Researchers reported hundreds of confirmed compromises and thousands of exposed servers, with multiple U.S. federal agencies (e.g., DOE, DHS) affected. Defenders were urged to apply patches on an emergency basis and take immediate mitigation steps.

search_results.title: Exploitation of CLFS zero-day leads to ransomware activity
search_results.snippet: Microsoft disclosed that a Windows Common Log File System (CLFS) elevation-of-privilege zero‑day (CVE‑2025‑29824) was exploited post‑compromise by Storm‑2460 to dump credentials and deploy ransomware against a small number of targets across sectors. Security updates were released on April 8, 2025, and customers were urged to patch promptly and follow ransomware mitigations and detections.

search_results.title: Zero-click AI data leak flaw uncovered in Microsoft 365 Copilot
search_results.snippet: Researchers revealed EchoLeak (CVE‑2025‑32711), a zero‑click AI vulnerability that could exfiltrate sensitive Microsoft 365 Copilot data via prompt injection without user interaction. Microsoft patched it server‑side in May 2025 and reported no evidence of exploitation in the wild, requiring no customer action though highlighting new AI security risks.

What constraints on power availability t.query: What constraints on power availability threaten Microsoft datacenter expansions in 2025-2026?
What constraints on power availability t.answer: Microsoft’s 2025–2026 buildout is being limited by utility-deliverable power in key markets, long transmission/interconnection timelines, and regional connection moratoriums. The company has acknowledged being short of both power and space, is diverting investment away from constrained hubs like Dublin (where new grid connections are effectively halted until at least 2028), and is securing dedicated generation (e.g., a long-term nuclear PPA) to mitigate grid bottlenecks.

search_results.title: Microsoft Azure earnings grow but disappoint, company blames data center capacity constraints
search_results.snippet: On its Jan. 2025 earnings call, Microsoft said Azure growth was capped by capacity—CFO Amy Hood described operating from a “capacity-constrained place” and noted the company has been “short of power and space,” with heavy capex aimed at adding long-lived infrastructure. The comments underscore that limited utility power and site readiness are gating Microsoft’s near-term data center expansions.

search_results.title: Microsoft shifting data center focus away from Ireland due to lack of power availability - report
search_results.snippet: Microsoft’s VP of lease and land said chronic grid constraints in Ireland are stifling development, pushing the company to redirect investment to the Nordics. With EirGrid’s de facto moratorium on new Dublin data center connections expected to last until at least 2028, Microsoft is effectively “closed in Dublin” to new customers—highlighting power access as a decisive limiter of 2025–2026 expansion.

search_results.title: Microsoft plans $80B for data centers as power constraints loom
search_results.snippet: Microsoft plans to invest ~$80B in FY2025 AI infrastructure but flags power as a fundamental challenge; data centers “don’t get built overnight.” To secure reliable supply amid grid bottlenecks, Microsoft signed a 20-year deal tied to restarting the Three Mile Island reactor (≈835–837 MW) to match loads in PA, VA, OH and Chicago—illustrating how power availability is shaping where and how it can expand.

What regulatory risks does Microsoft fac.query: What regulatory risks does Microsoft face under the EU Digital Markets Act in 2025?
What regulatory risks does Microsoft fac.answer: In 2025, Microsoft is a DMA gatekeeper for Windows PC OS and LinkedIn, and the European Commission is actively scrutinizing its compliance. The Commission’s 2025 workshop highlights risk areas around Articles 5(2), 6(3), 6(7), 6(9), and 6(10): consent-based limits on cross-service data combination (especially on LinkedIn), data portability and business-user access, Windows default/uninstall behavior and interoperability, and how new AI features (e.g., Copilot/Recall) interact with these rules. If found non‑compliant, Microsoft faces fines up to 10% of global turnover (20% for repeat infringements), periodic penalty payments, and potentially structural remedies for systematic breaches.

What geopolitical risks affect Microsoft.query: What geopolitical risks affect Microsoft's operations and sales in China during 2025?
What geopolitical risks affect Microsoft.answer: In 2025, Microsoft faces three major China-related geopolitical risks: Beijing’s drive to localize government and state-sector IT is replacing foreign operating systems and software (including Windows) with approved domestic alternatives, squeezing public-sector sales. China’s cybersecurity and data-sovereignty regime (CSL, DSL, PIPL) forces strict data localization, security assessments for cross‑border transfers, and compliance steps like real‑name verification and ICP filings, complicating Azure/Copilot delivery via 21Vianet. At the same time, new U.S. controls on advanced computing and AI model weights tighten export rules, potentially limiting Microsoft’s ability to provide frontier AI capabilities and related cloud services to Chinese customers.

search_results.title: Framework for Artificial Intelligence Diffusion; Interim Final Rule
search_results.snippet: In Jan 2025, the U.S. Commerce Department’s BIS tightened export controls on advanced computing chips and added new controls on certain AI model weights, with updated licensing policies and a Data Center VEU authorization. The rule aims to curb diffusion of frontier AI to countries of concern and takes effect mid‑2025, which can constrain U.S. firms’ ability to export or provide advanced AI capabilities to Chinese users via cloud or hardware.

search_results.title: Data sovereignty and China regulations
search_results.snippet: Microsoft explains that China’s CSL, DSL and PIPL impose strict data localization and cross‑border transfer controls: CII operators must store personal information and “important data” in China and undergo CAC security assessments. Azure China is operated by 21Vianet to support compliance, but customers still face real‑name verification, ICP/public‑security filings, and potential enforcement—raising operational complexity and cost for cloud services in China.

search_results.title: China chips away at use of Intel and AMD units in government computers
search_results.snippet: China has begun phasing out U.S. tech in government PCs and servers, telling agencies to buy “safe and reliable” domestic CPUs and operating systems. The move, which also seeks to sideline Microsoft’s Windows in the public sector, is part of a broader localization push that narrows opportunities for foreign software vendors and undercuts Microsoft’s government‑related OS and enterprise sales.

How does Microsoft price Azure OpenAI us.query: How does Microsoft price Azure OpenAI usage versus Google Vertex AI in 2025?
How does Microsoft price Azure OpenAI us.answer: In 2025, both platforms use usage-based pricing, but with different levers. Azure OpenAI prices per model and per 1M tokens with separate rates for input, cached input, and output; it offers Standard pay‑as‑you‑go, reserved Provisioned Throughput Units, and a Batch API that halves global rates. Vertex AI prices Gemini per 1M tokens with distinct input/output rates, ~50% Batch discounts, context caching, and charges for grounded prompts; long contexts (>200k tokens) use higher rates. For example, Azure GPT‑4.1 Global lists $2/M input and $8/M output tokens, while Gemini 2.5 Pro is $1.25/M input and $10/M output.

search_results.title: Azure OpenAI Service - Pricing | Microsoft Azure
search_results.snippet: Azure OpenAI bills per model and per 1M tokens, with separate prices for input, cached input, and output; customers can use Standard pay‑as‑you‑go, reserved Provisioned Throughput Units, or a Batch API that applies a 50% discount to global rates. Pricing also varies by deployment scope (Global, Data Zone, Regional); for example, GPT‑4.1 Global is listed at $2/M input tokens and $8/M output tokens.

search_results.title: Generative AI on Vertex AI pricing | Google Cloud
search_results.snippet: Vertex AI prices Gemini by 1M tokens with distinct input and output rates, optional context caching, and ~50% cheaper Batch API; long contexts (>200K tokens) are billed at higher rates. Gemini 2.5 Pro shows $1.25/M input and $10/M output tokens (long context $2.50/$15), and grounding with Google Search includes daily free prompts before $35 per 1,000 grounded prompts.

What EU data privacy rulings affected Mi.query: What EU data privacy rulings affected Microsoft cloud data transfers in 2025?
What EU data privacy rulings affected Mi.answer: In 2025, the European Data Protection Supervisor (EDPS) closed its enforcement against the European Commission’s use of Microsoft 365 after the Commission and Microsoft amended terms to strictly control cross‑border transfers. The updated arrangements limit transfers outside the EU/EEA to listed countries based on adequacy decisions or the ‘important public interest’ derogation, add binding instructions to Microsoft and sub‑processors, and require that disclosures and notification limits rely only on EU/Member‑State law or third‑country laws offering essentially equivalent protection.

search_results.title: Closure of enforcement proceedings in the Commission’s use of Microsoft 365
search_results.snippet: In a letter dated 11 July 2025, the EDPS closed enforcement after the Commission clarified data categories and purposes, identified third‑country recipients, issued binding instructions to Microsoft and sub‑processors, and limited any exceptional transfers to non‑adequate countries via Article 50(1)(d); disclosures for data processed in the EEA may occur only under EU/Member‑State law, and outside the EEA only under third‑country law offering essentially equivalent protection.

search_results.title: Cloud GDPR risks highlighted by European Commission ruling over Microsoft 365 use
search_results.snippet: This analysis explains that in July 2025 the EDPS confirmed compliance after requiring the Commission to map transfer destinations and purposes, restrict transfers to specified countries under adequacy or public‑interest derogations, and add contractual safeguards so Microsoft cannot disclose EU data or withhold notifications except under EU law or third‑country laws providing essentially equivalent protection.

What is Microsoft's 2025 grid-edge or on.query: What is Microsoft's 2025 grid-edge or on-site generation strategy to power AI datacenters?
What is Microsoft's 2025 grid-edge or on.answer: Microsoft’s 2025 approach blends grid-edge and on-site generation to meet fast-growing AI datacenter loads. It is rolling out grid-interactive UPS battery systems that can discharge or reduce load to support the grid and enable more renewables (piloted in Dublin, with plans to replicate globally). In parallel, Microsoft is piloting on-site microgrids and hydrogen fuel-cell backup to replace diesel (e.g., a 1.5 MW fuel-cell + BESS system that ran a datacenter for 48 hours). Where grids are constrained, Microsoft has secured permits for on-site gas-fired generation (e.g., a 170 MW plant at Dublin’s Grange Castle) to operate as backup or alternative supply and reduce strain on the local grid.

What export control policies affected Mi.query: What export control policies affected Microsoft's AI or cloud services to China in 2025?
What export control policies affected Mi.answer: In 2025, the U.S. Commerce Department’s BIS issued the Framework for Artificial Intelligence Diffusion (Jan 15), creating worldwide controls on advanced AI chips and certain closed AI model weights and introducing data‑center Validated End‑User programs and security conditions to limit access in destinations of concern, including China. On May 13, BIS further clarified that providing advanced compute—including via foreign IaaS/cloud providers—to train AI models for or on behalf of parties headquartered in China can trigger EAR license requirements and U.S.-person restrictions. Together, these measures directly constrained how Microsoft’s Azure AI/cloud services could be provided to Chinese customers.

search_results.title: BIS Policy Statement on Controls that May Apply to Advanced Computing Integrated Circuits and Other Commodities Used to Train AI Models May 13, 2025
search_results.snippet: BIS warns that exports, reexports, or in‑country transfers of advanced computing ICs and related items—including through foreign IaaS/cloud providers—may require a license when used to train AI models for or on behalf of parties headquartered in D:5 countries (including China) or Macau; it also cautions that U.S. persons providing support for such training can trigger EAR controls, urging heightened KYC and red‑flag due diligence.

search_results.title: Framework for Artificial Intelligence Diffusion
search_results.snippet: The Jan 15, 2025 BIS interim final rule establishes a global licensing regime on advanced AI chips (e.g., 3A090/4A090) and adds controls on certain closed‑weight AI model weights; it creates Data Center Validated End‑User authorizations (UVEU/NVEU) with security conditions to enable exports to trusted partners while restricting access to frontier compute in destinations of concern, including China.

search_results.title: What to Know About the New U.S. AI Diffusion Policy and Export Controls
search_results.snippet: CFR explains the framework’s tiered country approach that presumes D:5 destinations like China are ineligible for advanced U.S. AI tech, regulates cloud access to close the loophole of PRC firms renting compute abroad, and requires licenses for exports of certain closed‑weight model weights—directly impacting how U.S. hyperscalers (e.g., Microsoft) can provide AI services.

report:
# MSFT | Microsoft Corporation — Equity Research Update

## 1) Investment Recommendation Summary
- Stance: BULLISH
- Rating: BUY
- Next Market Day View: Modestly positive skew. We expect MSFT to trade with an upward bias next session as investors continue to price in Azure’s accelerating growth, durable FY26 margin guidance, and strengthening AI monetization, while near‑term cloud gross margin headwinds and capacity/power constraints remain watch items [47][48][2][3][4][7][8][24][25].

---

## 2) Executive Summary
Microsoft’s cloud and AI flywheel continues to strengthen. Azure growth accelerated to 39% YoY in Q4 FY25, Microsoft Cloud delivered $46.7B in quarterly revenue (≈$187B run-rate), and management guided Q1 FY26 Azure growth of about 37% in constant currency with segment revenue outlooks above seasonal norms [47][48][1][12][9][10][11]. While AI infrastructure scale-up is diluting cloud gross margins near term (Q1 FY26 cloud GM guided to ~67% vs 71% in the prior-year quarter; Q4 FY25 cloud GM 68%, down 2 pts YoY) [7][8][13], the CFO targets FY26 operating margins to be relatively unchanged YoY—signaling confidence that efficiencies, mix management, and useful life extensions can offset investment pressure as capacity ramps [2][3][4].

Strategically, Microsoft is securing multi-vendor GPU supply (NVIDIA GB200, AMD MI300X/MI325X), advancing in-house silicon (Cobalt GA; Maia next-gen now expected 2026), and locking down long-term power and grid agreements—all aimed at alleviating capacity constraints that have capped Azure growth [19][20][40][41][42][37][36][38][24][33][34][35][25]. Customer traction and monetization are broadening (AI revenue run-rate reached $13B; major wins such as GSA OneGov and Navy sole‑source cloud), although Azure churn and Azure OpenAI enterprise customer counts remain undisclosed [16][17][31][32][14][15][1]. Regulatory overhang is real (EU Teams unbundling commitments; UK CMA SMS investigations), but clarity is improving with defined commitments and oversight mechanisms [30][29].

Bottom line: With accelerating Azure, expanding AI monetization, firm capex execution, and strong balance sheet support, we see a constructive setup into FY26. We rate MSFT BUY.

---

## 3) Company Overview
- Segments: Productivity & Business Processes; Intelligent Cloud; More Personal Computing.
- Scale and momentum:
  - Microsoft Cloud revenue: $46.7B in Q4 FY25 (up 27% YoY); annualized run-rate ≈$187B [1][12].
  - Azure and other cloud services growth: 39% YoY in Q4 FY25; Q1 FY26 Azure growth guided ~37% in constant currency [47][48][9][10].
  - Azure annual revenue surpassed $75B as of Q4 FY25 [1][14].
  - AI business annual revenue run-rate reached $13B as of FY25 Q2; AI added 13 pts to Azure growth that quarter [16][17].
- Market position: Global cloud IaaS/PaaS share per Synergy in Q2 2025—AWS 30%, Azure 20%, Google Cloud 13% [18].

---

## 4) Key Findings by Category

### Revenue and Growth
- Q4 FY25:
  - Microsoft Cloud revenue $46.7B (+27% YoY) [1].
  - Azure and other cloud services +39% YoY [47][48].
  - Cloud run-rate ≈$187B (annualized Q4) [1][12].
- Q1 FY26 outlook:
  - Productivity & Business Processes (PBP): $32.2–$32.5B
  - Intelligent Cloud (IC): $30.1–$30.4B
  - More Personal Computing (MPC): $12.4–$12.9B
  - Azure growth: ~37% in constant currency; FX +~2 pts to total revenue growth; capex >$30B in Q1 [9][10][11].
  - Within MPC: Windows OEM & Devices to decline mid/high-single digits; Search & News ex‑TAC to grow low/mid-teens; Gaming to decline mid/high-single digits [13].

### Margins, Profitability, and Capex
- Cloud GM trends:
  - Q4 FY25 cloud GM 68%, down 2 pts YoY, with AI infrastructure scaling the primary driver; company-level GM 69%, down 1 pt [13].
  - Q1 FY26 cloud GM guided ~67% vs 71% in the prior-year quarter—~4 pts YoY headwind from AI build-out [7][8].
- Operating margin outlook FY26: “Relatively unchanged” vs FY25 despite ongoing AI scale-up; management cites efficiency gains, useful-life extensions, and mix optimization as offsets; headcount flat even as capex elevates [2][3][4].
- Capex and depreciation:
  - Q1 FY26 capex >$30B; FY26 capex growth to slow vs FY25, with a higher mix of short-lived assets (servers/GPUs/networking), implying higher depreciation as AI capacity enters service [9][2][26].

### Cloud Capacity, Silicon, and Supply Chain
- NVIDIA: Azure ND GB200 v6 VMs GA; Blackwell Ultra‑based VMs to follow in 2025—expanding training and inference performance envelopes [19].
- AMD: Azure ND MI300X v5 VMs in production; MI325X in mass production in Q4 2024 with shipments to customers (incl. hyperscalers) starting Q1 2025 [20][41][42][40].
- Microsoft silicon:
  - Cobalt 100-based VMs GA and expanding regionally [37].
  - Maia next-gen (Maia 200/“Braga”) mass production pushed into 2026; roadmap shows Braga‑R (2026) and Clea (Maia 300) in 2027 [36][38].
- Memory: SK hynix engaged for customized HBM for Microsoft AI builds, with first shipments expected from 2H 2025 [39].

### Power, Real Estate, and Infrastructure Execution
- Constraints: Management has operated “capacity-constrained,” short of power and space; AI build-outs are long‑lived and capital intensive [24].
- Long‑term power strategy:
  - 20-year agreement tied to restarting Three Mile Island reactor to match loads across key hubs, addressing looming grid bottlenecks [25].
  - Utility partnerships and tariffs: 15-year Chelan PUD agreement (max 288 MW); large-load settlements in Indiana; special “very large” data center tariffs in Wisconsin designed to fund new generation and protect other ratepayers [33][34][35].

### Customer Traction and Monetization
- AI monetization: AI run-rate reached $13B; Azure growth benefited from 13 points of AI contribution in FY25 Q2 [16][17].
- Public-sector momentum and competitive wins:
  - GSA OneGov: government-wide agreement delivering steep discounts for Microsoft 365, Copilot, and Azure [31].
  - U.S. Navy sole-source cloud contract (JWCC) awarded to Microsoft; switching providers deemed too risky and time consuming—win over AWS/Google/Oracle for mission needs [32].
- Copilot adoption and pricing:
  - Microsoft cites Copilot usage by >100M commercial and consumer users and adoption across >70% of the Fortune 500 [44].
  - Commercial seat base ~430M paid M365/Office 365; paid Copilot seat count not disclosed [43].
  - Pricing updates: Monthly billing option for Copilot annual subs at 5% uplift (effective Dec 1, 2024) and standardized 5% uplift for all monthly‑billed annual subs starting Apr 1, 2025; Copilot added to consumer M365 Personal/Family with $3/month price increase [45][46].

### Regulatory and Policy
- EU: Microsoft accepted binding commitments to unbundle Teams from Microsoft 365/Office in the EEA, enhance interoperability/data portability, and display with/without‑Teams options; commitments for 7–10 years with trustee oversight [30].
- UK CMA: Final decision recommends commencing Strategic Market Status investigations for Microsoft and AWS to address identified competition issues in cloud services [29].

### Capital Structure and Returns
- Balance sheet: Net cash position of ~ $51.4B as of June 30, 2025 (cash and ST investments $94.6B; total debt ~$43.2B; excludes leases) [5][6].
- Shareholder returns: New $60B repurchase authorization approved Sept 16, 2024 (no expiration; begins after prior plan completion) [27]; quarterly dividend raised 10% to $0.91 on Sept 15, 2025 [28].

### Disclosures Not Provided
- Azure enterprise churn rate: Not disclosed [14][15].
- Azure OpenAI Service enterprise customer count: Not disclosed in Q4 FY25 materials [1].

---

## 5) Investment Thesis

Bull case
- Azure reacceleration with visible demand and capacity additions. Q4 FY25 Azure growth accelerated to 39% and Q1 FY26 is guided to ~37% cc, supported by constrained but expanding capacity and robust AI demand [47][48][9][10][11].
- AI monetization ramp. AI revenue run-rate reached $13B; AI contributed 13 pts to Azure growth in FY25 Q2, indicating strong attach and pricing potential across Copilot, Azure AI services, and enterprise workloads [16][17].
- Operating margin durability despite AI build-out. Management expects FY26 operating margins to be “relatively unchanged,” offsetting cloud GM pressure through efficiency gains, useful-life extensions, and mix management [2][3][4][7][8].
- Capacity and supply chain de-risking. Multi-vendor GPU roadmap (NVIDIA GB200; AMD MI300X/MI325X), in-house silicon progression (Cobalt GA), HBM supply engagements, and long-term power deals address prior constraints that capped growth [19][20][40][41][42][37][36][39][24][25][33][34][35].
- Enterprise/ public sector wins. GSA OneGov and Navy sole‑source wins underscore competitive strength vs AWS and create durable workloads and AI attach opportunities [31][32].
- Balance sheet and returns. Substantial net cash, $60B buyback authorization, and dividend growth support total return and downside resilience [5][6][27][28].

Bear case
- Margin headwinds from AI infrastructure. Cloud GM down 2 pts YoY in Q4 FY25 and guided to ~67% in Q1 FY26 vs 71% in the prior-year quarter as AI scale-up weighs on mix; depreciation to rise as short-lived assets ramp [13][7][8][26].
- Capacity and power bottlenecks. Management acknowledged operating “short of power and space,” and grid readiness could limit how fast demand converts to revenue despite large capex [24][25].
- Regulatory friction. EU Teams unbundling and potential UK SMS designation could introduce pricing and bundling headwinds or compliance costs that slow monetization in parts of PBP [30][29].
- Execution risk in custom silicon. Maia 200 mass production pushed to 2026; any slippage or performance gaps vs merchant silicon could delay cost/performance benefits [36].
- Competitive intensity. AWS remains the share leader; Google Cloud is pressing in AI workloads. Azure share at 20% vs AWS 30% leaves a wide competitive field [18].
- Limited disclosure. No Azure churn or Azure OpenAI enterprise customer counts, constraining cohort analysis and unit economics transparency [14][15][1].

---

## 6) Key Risks
- Prolonged cloud gross margin compression from AI build-out and higher depreciation as capacity enters service [7][8][13][26].
- Supply chain tightness in GPUs/HBM or delays in custom silicon schedules (Maia) could impede capacity adds or raise costs [36][39][19][20][41][42].
- Power constraints and grid interconnect timing could cap Azure growth despite demand [24][25][33][34][35].
- Adverse regulatory outcomes in the EU/UK around bundling, interoperability, or potential SMS remedies could impact pricing, attach, and sales motions [30][29].
- Macro and PC/gaming cycles pressuring MPC segment; Windows OEM & Devices guided down mid/high-single digits in Q1 FY26; Gaming down mid/high-single digits [13].

---

## 7) Conclusion and Outlook

- Recommendation: BUY (BULLISH). We favor MSFT on sustained Azure momentum, accelerating AI monetization, capacity/supply de‑risking, and a credible margin framework that aims to keep FY26 operating margins relatively unchanged despite heavy AI investment [47][48][16][17][2][3][4].
- Next Market Day Prediction: Modestly positive bias. We expect shares to reflect the constructive setup of Azure reacceleration and FY26 operating discipline, balanced against acknowledged cloud GM pressure and capacity/power risks [47][48][2][3][4][7][8][24][25].
- Near-term catalysts to watch:
  - Any updates on Q1 FY26 demand cadence relative to guidance (segments and Azure growth) [9][10][11].
  - Evidence of easing capacity constraints via GPU deliveries (NVIDIA GB200, AMD MI325X) and power/project milestones [19][41][42][33][35].
  - Copilot adoption/pricing traction and enterprise AI attach rates; monetization signals beyond the $13B AI run-rate [16][17][45][46].
  - Regulatory implementation of EU Teams commitments and UK CMA actions [30][29].

On balance, we see a favorable risk‑reward into FY26 as Microsoft scales AI while preserving operating margin discipline, underpinned by an outstanding balance sheet and capital returns [2][3][4][5][6][27][28].
